item.title: Benchmarking for material Simulation package-OpenMX
item.description:
Aug. 2015-Oct. 2015
Authors: Kuan Zhou, Roger K. Lake

OpenMX is an open-source software package for nano-scale material simulations based on density functional theories (DFT), norm-conserving pseudopotentials, and pseudo- atomic localized basis functions. Systems consisting of 1000 atoms can be treated using the conventional diagonalization method. Non-quilibrium Green functions (NEGF) is also implemented into the package. To help calculate electron transport for several systems with large computing requirements, I benchmarked the performance of this software.

item.title: Interlayer Resistivity of Misoriented MoS2
item.description:
Dec. 2014-Feb. 2017
Authors: Kuan Zhou, Darshana Wickramaratne, Supeng Ge, Shanshan Su, Amrit De, Roger K. Lake

The electron and hole interlayer resistivities of misoriented bilayer MoS2 were deter- mined as a function of the misorientation angle. The approach employed electronic structure calculations using the Vienna Ab initio simulation package (VASP) combined with NEGF calculations of the interlayer resistivity. I found that the electron and hole resistivities differed by several orders of magnitude depending on the rotation angle, and how this property could be exploited in the design of a high-frequency bipolar junction transistor or heterostructure bipolar transistor. This work has been published in Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics.

item.title: Optimization of GRAPE algorithm in quantum control techniques
item.description:
June 2012-June 2013
Authors: Kuan Zhou, Nanyang Xu, Xinhua Peng

I developed quantum control techniques in NMR systems, including optimization of the Gradient Ascent Pulse Engineering algorithm (GRAPE), and completed the task of algorithm development and pulse calculations in 5-bit systems.
